quotes.text: I have this idea that I call the feather brick dump truck phenomenon, and basically what that means is when we are showing early signs of burnout, our body will give us feedback usually in subtle ways in the beginning.
quotes.speaker: Jonny Miller
quotes.context: Introduces a memorable burnout escalation framework that helps practitioners spot early warning signals before they compound.

quotes.text: So the feather might be waking up in the morning and feeling a little bit tired, maybe a little bit exhausted.
quotes.speaker: Jonny Miller
quotes.context: Gives a concrete example of a subtle, early-stage burnout signal people can learn to notice and act on.

quotes.text: The brick, maybe you ignore that or you don't notice it, and then three or four weeks later, you have a fight with someone or an argument, or you just feel frustrated and terrible and you lose your cool.
quotes.speaker: Jonny Miller
quotes.context: Shows how ignored early signals can escalate into interpersonal and emotional blowups on a realistic timeline.

quotes.text: Ideally, you want to notice when it's the feather and then make adjustments or shift then and not have to wait until you experience the full-blown pain of the dump truck, which unfortunately is what happens to a lot of people, especially when they experience burnout for the first time.
quotes.speaker: Jonny Miller
quotes.context: Actionable guidance: intervene early (at the 'feather' stage) to prevent severe burnout consequences.

quotes.text: If you can get better at dealing with stressful situations, avoiding burnout and being more confident in meetings and big presentations, it becomes a superpower and a huge advantage in both business and in life.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Frames nervous system skills as a high-leverage capability with direct professional and personal upside.

quotes.text: We talk about why the best way to stay calm in stressful situations is to focus on the state of your body and not your mind.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: A counterintuitive reframe that prioritizes somatic state over cognitive control for staying calm under pressure.

quotes.text: How to create calm and confidence by changing the state of your body through breath.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Highlights breathwork as a practical mechanism for shifting emotional state on demand.

quotes.text: Also, a practice called APE, which reminds you to focus on your awareness, your posture, and your emotions that have started practicing ever since our chat and so much more.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Introduces a memorable framework (APE) for quickly checking and adjusting internal state in real time.

quotes.text: This time of year is prime for career reflection and setting goals for professional growth.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: A simple seasonal trigger practitioners can use to schedule an annual career review and goal-setting ritual.

quotes.text: I always like to spend this time reflecting on what I accomplished the previous year, what I hope to accomplish the next year, and whether this is the year I look for a new opportunity.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: A practical 3-part reflection framework for deciding whether to stay, grow, or change roles.

quotes.text: Teal provides you with the tools to run an amazing job search with an AI-powered resume builder, job tracker, cover letter generator, and Chrome extension that integrates with over 40 job boards.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: A concrete example of assembling a job-search “system” (assets + tracking + distribution) rather than relying on ad hoc applications.

quotes.text: There's a reason nearly 1 million people have trusted Teal to run their job search.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: A specific adoption data point that signals the scale of usage and social proof in a competitive job-search market.

quotes.text: Over 5,000 fast-growing companies use Vanta to automate up to 90% of the work involved with SOC 2 and these other frameworks.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: A concrete benchmark for how much compliance work can be automated, useful for estimating ROI and resourcing.

quotes.topic_title: Jonny’s origin story and catalyst event
quotes.text: I find that usually people that get into this type of work, there's some kind of catalyst or some kind of challenging life event.
quotes.speaker: Jonny Miller
quotes.context: A useful mental model for understanding (and looking for) the “catalyst event” that often drives deep behavior change and commitment to inner work.

quotes.topic_title: Jonny’s origin story and catalyst event
quotes.text: And I realized that I'd been so disconnected from my body and my emotions, and it sent me on this five plus year journey to discover all of this inner landscape that I'd been numb from the neck down,
quotes.speaker: Jonny Miller
quotes.context: Highlights a practitioner-relevant diagnostic: anxiety/burnout can be rooted in disconnection from bodily/emotional signals, not just thoughts.

quotes.topic_title: Jonny’s origin story and catalyst event
quotes.text: I went into breathwork meditation retreats, did hundreds of breathwork journeys, researched with a breath lab over in Bali, and basically just kind of directed all of my focus and attention onto understanding this inner landscape that I'd been pretty much oblivious to.
quotes.speaker: Jonny Miller
quotes.context: Gives concrete modalities (breathwork, meditation retreats) plus a specific example (“hundreds of breathwork journeys”) that practitioners can emulate or explore.

quotes.topic_title: Jonny’s origin story and catalyst event
quotes.text: And also just since realizing how many people are struggling with anxiety, depression, all of this kind of constellation of mental health challenges both in the workplace and at home as well.
quotes.speaker: Jonny Miller
quotes.context: Frames mental health as a broad “constellation” spanning work and home—useful for leaders designing support beyond narrow workplace-only interventions.

quotes.text: But in my experience, working with the physiology, using what's known as a bottom up approach, primarily using the breath, although there's also other approaches that you can use, it's just such a rapidly more effective way of shifting your state.
quotes.speaker: Jonny Miller
quotes.context: A clear practitioner-oriented claim that bottom-up (physiology-first) regulation—especially breathwork—often outperforms cognitive reframing for fast state change.

quotes.text: there's four times more afferent neurons going from the body to the brain as from the brain to the body.
quotes.speaker: Jonny Miller
quotes.context: A concrete data point supporting the rationale for prioritizing body-to-brain interventions when trying to shift thoughts and emotions.

quotes.text: So instead of trying to change the story or trying to fix something or trying to solve something, which is what most people do by default, myself included in the past, if you change your state first, then there's a cascading effect which changes your thoughts and your feelings.
quotes.speaker: Jonny Miller
quotes.context: A memorable methodology: change physiological state first to create downstream improvements in cognition and emotion.

quotes.text: what scientists have discovered that when the exhale is twice as long as the inhale, it has a calming effect. And when the inhale is either more intense or twice as long as the exhale, it has an activating effect. So you can kind of think of this as an up or down lever on the nervous system.
quotes.speaker: Jonny Miller
quotes.context: Highly actionable breath “protocol” framed as a simple control lever for dialing arousal up or down.

quotes.text: I gave a TEDx talk a few years ago and I was like my entire body, I was just terrified. And I did in 15 minutes of this breathing practice before and walked on stage almost cool as a cucumber. It's very effective.
quotes.speaker: Jonny Miller
quotes.context: A specific example illustrating how quickly breathwork can shift performance anxiety in a high-stakes setting.

quotes.text: We can stack a few of the exercises and I'll try and keep it to a minute or so.
quotes.speaker: Jonny Miller
quotes.context: Introduces a practical methodology of combining multiple calming techniques into a short, repeatable routine.

quotes.text: We're going to inhale in through the nose for four. We're going to hold the breath at the top for four, and we're going to exhale for eight, and then we're going to repeat.
quotes.speaker: Jonny Miller
quotes.context: Gives a clear, actionable breathing protocol (4-4-8) that listeners can apply immediately.

quotes.text: And now you can let go of the breath completely and we'll end with one round of humming, which is surprisingly effect of it calming as well.
quotes.speaker: Jonny Miller
quotes.context: Adds a counterintuitive “humming” layer to deepen calm beyond standard breathwork.

quotes.text: A note on the humming. It also releases nitric oxide, which is a vasodilator, and that helps to create that kind of calming effect and it also reduces eye tension as well.
quotes.speaker: Jonny Miller
quotes.context: Explains a concrete physiological mechanism and an additional benefit (reduced eye tension) that makes the technique more compelling to use.

quotes.text: So it kind of tones or stimulates the vagus nerve, which stimulates the parasympathetic nervous system.
quotes.speaker: Jonny Miller
quotes.context: Connects humming to vagus nerve stimulation as a mechanism for shifting into a calmer parasympathetic state.

quotes.text: I kind of like to share building a toolkit of different practices that are appropriate for different contexts.
quotes.speaker: Jonny Miller
quotes.context: A practical mental model: don’t rely on one technique—match regulation practices to the situation you’re in.

quotes.text: So I like to kind of give people a big toolkit to see what works for them and then cherry-pick which ones are suitable to different situations.
quotes.speaker: Jonny Miller
quotes.context: Actionable guidance for personalization: experiment broadly, then select context-appropriate tools you’ll actually use.

quotes.text: And another way that I think about this is, I call it, if this, then breathe.
quotes.speaker: Jonny Miller
quotes.context: A memorable framework for making self-regulation automatic by tying it to simple triggers.

quotes.text: So it's like if I feel overwhelmed, then I do the humming. If I feel anxious, then I do 4, 4, 8 breathing or alternate nostril breathing and kind of having my own little recipe set that I have for different context is really helpful and I work with people to kind of build those toolkits themselves.
quotes.speaker: Jonny Miller
quotes.context: Concrete “if-then” examples practitioners can copy to build a repeatable, situation-specific regulation playbook.

quotes.text: I'd also add that the sigh happens naturally as a result of doing these downshifting practices.
quotes.speaker: Jonny Miller
quotes.context: A counterintuitive observation: the sigh can be a downstream signal of regulation, not just a technique you force.

quotes.text: He calls it the physiological sigh, and it's both very effective, especially if you just have five seconds and you just take a full sigh, it's great.
quotes.speaker: Jonny Miller
quotes.context: A concrete, time-efficient tool practitioners can use immediately to calm down in the moment.

quotes.text: I'd also add that the sigh happens naturally as a result of doing these downshifting practices.
quotes.speaker: Jonny Miller
quotes.context: Reframes sighing as a built-in physiological marker of successful nervous system downregulation, not just a technique.

quotes.text: So if you notice after you do let's say the 4, 4, 8 breathing, at the end, you might naturally just want to let out a sigh, and that's a signal that your body is naturally downshifting.
quotes.speaker: Jonny Miller
quotes.context: Gives a specific example (4, 4, 8 breathing) and a diagnostic cue to recognize when the body is shifting into calm.

quotes.text: Or if you are with a friend and you feel just comfortable and relaxed, then your body might sigh.
quotes.speaker: Jonny Miller
quotes.context: Highlights a counterintuitive observation that sighing can indicate safety/relaxation, not only stress or frustration.

quotes.text: And it's something that we do a lot and as you say, you can consciously do it and that will help as well.
quotes.speaker: Jonny Miller
quotes.context: Connects an unconscious physiological behavior to a deliberate practice people can intentionally deploy for regulation.

quotes.text: I would only recommend this if you're feeling lethargic or maybe instead of drinking a coffee in the afternoon, you could do this for a minute or so.
quotes.speaker: Jonny Miller
quotes.context: Clear guidance on when to use the activating breath drill as a practical substitute for caffeine.

quotes.text: I like to keep it through the nose only if you do it through the mouth, it can be very too activating and it can kind of overwhelm people.
quotes.speaker: Jonny Miller
quotes.context: A tactical constraint (nasal-only) that reduces the risk of over-activation and makes the practice safer to apply.

quotes.text: If Wim Hof is like Red Bull, this is kind of like a small coffee.
quotes.speaker: Jonny Miller
quotes.context: Memorable mental model for calibrating intensity and choosing a gentler activation method.

quotes.text: So it kind of depends on how activating you find it, but I usually find 30 breaths per round and then take a breath, have a long pause on the exhale, and then if you want to do another round or two.
quotes.speaker: Jonny Miller
quotes.context: Concrete protocol (dose + pacing) that practitioners can follow immediately.

quotes.text: you can do the espresso breath to begin with and that activates you. And then do some of the downshifting practices to kind of ground and stabilize that aliveness.
quotes.speaker: Jonny Miller
quotes.context: A sequencing methodology: pair activation first with later grounding to avoid staying overstimulated.

quotes.topic_title: Practice design: daily reps to remember under stress
quotes.text: So I like to recommend both a morning practice, particularly to build the muscle of just doing it and getting used to it. So maybe five minutes in the morning before you start work, before breakfast, something like that.
quotes.speaker: Jonny Miller
quotes.context: A concrete “daily reps” practice design (5 minutes in the morning) to make the tools automatic under stress.

quotes.topic_title: Practice design: daily reps to remember under stress
quotes.text: So by having a deliberate practice for at least 7 to 10 days and so that you get the hang of it, then it feels much more natural to do it when you're feeling. That's kind of like playing the game on hard mode when you are really stressed and anxious, that's when you need it the most, but it's also when you're least likely to remember to do it.
quotes.speaker: Jonny Miller
quotes.context: A memorable mental model (“hard mode”) plus a specific timeframe (7–10 days) for building recall when stressed.

quotes.topic_title: Practice design: daily reps to remember under stress
quotes.text: I'll also add that the important thing is that the exhale is twice as long as the inhale. So if exhaling for eight is too long, you could do 3, 3, 6 or even 2, 2, 4 or even 5, 5, 10 depending on your lung capacity essentially and your CO2 tolerance.
quotes.speaker: Jonny Miller
quotes.context: A flexible breathing rule (2:1 exhale:inhale) with multiple ratios to adapt to capacity and CO2 tolerance.

quotes.topic_title: Practice design: daily reps to remember under stress
quotes.text: Two to three rounds of 30 pumps, yeah.
quotes.speaker: Jonny Miller
quotes.context: A precise dosage for the energizing “espresso breath” technique.

quotes.topic_title: Practice design: daily reps to remember under stress
quotes.text: And the reason I bring it in is because if you do this practice but you're not really aware of your body and how you feel, then it'll be less compelling to you. But if you're kind of tuned into like sensations in your body, what's going on, you're more likely to notice the difference in the shifts.
quotes.speaker: Jonny Miller
quotes.context: Highlights interoception/somatic awareness as the amplifier that makes the practice feel meaningful and reinforces adherence.

quotes.text: So it's this idea of interoception, which is known as our sixth sense, and basically it's our ability to sense, track and feel our internal landscape.
quotes.speaker: Jonny Miller
quotes.context: Defines interoception as a trainable internal-sensing capability, framing it as a practical skill rather than a vague concept.

quotes.text: And I like to use the metaphor of a chef in the same way that you train your flavor palette for kind of sweet, spicy, umami, things like that. You can also train your interoceptive palette and become more aware of the internal sensations, whether that's your breath, whether it's tension, whether it's moods and emotions, whether it's the quality of your awareness, the quality of your thoughts.
quotes.speaker: Jonny Miller
quotes.context: Offers a memorable mental model (“chef’s palate”) for systematically training body awareness across multiple internal signals.

quotes.text: And the more kind of in tune with that you are, the more likely you are to notice the kind of early warning signs of something like anxiety.
quotes.speaker: Jonny Miller
quotes.context: Connects improved interoception to earlier detection of anxiety, making it actionable as a prevention tool.

quotes.text: Because usually, certainly a panic attack doesn't come out of nowhere. There will be a kind of cascade of subtle things that happen in your body that eventually result in anxiety.
quotes.speaker: Jonny Miller
quotes.context: Challenges the common belief that panic is sudden by emphasizing detectable precursors practitioners can learn to spot.

quotes.text: One being that ADHD tends to correlate with low levels of interoception, as does if people have PTSD or trauma. Again, interoception is lowered.
quotes.speaker: Jonny Miller
quotes.context: Provides a research-backed data point linking interoception to ADHD/PTSD, suggesting where training may be especially relevant.

quotes.text: Yeah. So I simplify this to APE, which basically is an acronym which stands for awareness, posture, and emotion.
quotes.speaker: Jonny Miller
quotes.context: Introduces a simple, repeatable self-check framework for shifting state in real time.

quotes.text: Awareness is, to give an example, I could narrow my awareness and become really focused and just you kind of tense up and it also is quite activating sometimes or you can relax and expand your awareness and be aware of the space above me, the space behind me, the space below me. And that is generally a calming thing.
quotes.speaker: Jonny Miller
quotes.context: Gives a concrete, counterintuitive lever—widening awareness—to downshift nervous system activation quickly.

quotes.text: Instead of just tackling the problem on the level of the mind dropping down into the body and bringing that into the picture as well, I find to be really helpful.
quotes.speaker: Jonny Miller
quotes.context: Actionable guidance to interrupt racing thoughts by shifting attention from cognition to somatic signals.

quotes.text: There's an idea of email apnea when people are checking their emails, they will, without noticing it, start to hold their breath, which is generally a very activating thing to do.
quotes.speaker: Jonny Miller
quotes.context: Names a specific, common pattern that practitioners can notice and correct to reduce stress during routine work.

quotes.text: Basically, breathing without tension is ideal.
quotes.speaker: Jonny Miller
quotes.context: A memorable, practical heuristic for using breath as a quick diagnostic and regulation tool.

quotes.topic_title: Burnout detection via body signals and commitments
quotes.text: I remember I felt or got off the podcast and I felt pretty exhausted and I felt like there was this kind of tension in my chest.
quotes.speaker: Jonny Miller
quotes.context: A concrete example of using body signals (exhaustion, chest tension) as an early warning sign of overcommitment.

quotes.topic_title: Burnout detection via body signals and commitments
quotes.text: I realized that I had very much over committed myself for that week.
quotes.speaker: Jonny Miller
quotes.context: Highlights the practical diagnostic step: connecting physiological cues to the underlying cause (schedule overload).

quotes.topic_title: Burnout detection via body signals and commitments
quotes.text: The podcast wasn't even the priority for what I'm focusing on in this quarter, so I then made the decision to just push back all my episodes until the summer basically.
quotes.speaker: Jonny Miller
quotes.context: Shows an actionable burnout-prevention move: aligning commitments with quarterly priorities and cutting nonessential load.

quotes.topic_title: Burnout detection via body signals and commitments
quotes.text: Yeah, so I have this idea that I call the feather brick dump truck phenomenon.
quotes.speaker: Jonny Miller
quotes.context: Introduces a memorable mental model for escalating burnout signals that practitioners can use to self-monitor.

quotes.topic_title: Burnout detection via body signals and commitments
quotes.text: ideally, you want to notice when it's the feather and then make adjustments or shift then and not have to wait until you experience the full-blown pain of the dump truck, which unfortunately is what happens to a lot of people, especially when they experience burnout for the first time.
quotes.speaker: Jonny Miller
quotes.context: Actionable guidance to intervene early—at subtle signals—rather than waiting for a crisis to force change.

quotes.text: Miro helps you streamline your workflows, organize information, and get your whole team on the same page.
quotes.speaker: Speaker name
quotes.context: A concise, actionable summary of the core workflow benefits practitioners can aim for when choosing collaboration tooling.

quotes.text: check out my Miro board that the Miro team helped me create, which includes all of my favorite plug and play templates, like a user journey map, my favorite one pager template plus a brainstorming guide.
quotes.speaker: Speaker name
quotes.context: Provides concrete, reusable artifacts (templates) that teams can adopt immediately to standardize planning and ideation.

quotes.text: Make sure to check out some of my favorite features, like the sticky notes, the inline comments and charts, and also the really cool diagramming tools.
quotes.speaker: Speaker name
quotes.context: Calls out specific collaboration primitives teams can use to improve async communication and shared understanding.

quotes.text: Your first three Miro boards are free when you sign up today at miro.com/lenny.
quotes.speaker: Speaker name
quotes.context: A concrete offer that lowers the barrier to trying a new workflow system with minimal commitment.

quotes.text: So your advice here is just pay attention to these little signs that you're not living a sustainable life right now.
quotes.speaker: Speaker name
quotes.context: Introduces a practical self-monitoring heuristic—watching for small warning signs—to prompt earlier course correction.

quotes.topic_title: Emotional debt: allostatic load and early signs
quotes.text: Yeah, so I'll tie this in with a concept that I call emotional debt, which is basically when our nervous system experiences stress, there's known as a mobilization cycle, and if that cycle isn't completed or we don't get to downshift or relax on the other side, that gets stored in the body as allostatic load, which I call emotional debt.
quotes.speaker: Jonny Miller
quotes.context: Defines a practical framework (“emotional debt”) that links incomplete stress recovery to accumulating physiological load.

quotes.topic_title: Emotional debt: allostatic load and early signs
quotes.text: And over time, that creates fragility in the nervous system. And so what that fragility can look like is anything from being impacted by small things in a kind of disproportionate way. So noticing that you are more reactive than normal, maybe you're a little bit more snappy, maybe you get frustrated by little things, maybe your sleep isn't as good, maybe you wake up not feeling fully rested.
quotes.speaker: Jonny Miller
quotes.context: Gives concrete early warning signs practitioners can monitor before burnout escalates.

quotes.topic_title: Emotional debt: allostatic load and early signs
quotes.text: And then as that emotional debt threshold increases in the same way that say with technical debt, if you're building a product in the beginning, it's fine, and in fact it's even necessary in the beginning. It's great that our body can buffer the stress response because it allows us to function. But if we don't pay off that technical debt or emotional debt, then over time it accumulates and it can also come out through health crises, health challenges.
quotes.speaker: Jonny Miller
quotes.context: Uses a memorable technical-debt analogy and the counterintuitive point that stress-buffering is initially useful but becomes costly if not repaid.

quotes.topic_title: Emotional debt: allostatic load and early signs
quotes.text: What I've seen with some of my founder clients and in the research that we did where we interviewed 260 leaders, what can often happen is that emotional debt will increase and increase and increase until it gets to a point where we are well outside what's known as a window of tolerance. And at that point there's like a crash.
quotes.speaker: Jonny Miller
quotes.context: Adds a data point (260 leaders) and a progression model (window of tolerance → crash) that explains sudden burnout events.

quotes.topic_title: Emotional debt: allostatic load and early signs
quotes.text: Or one really key sign actually is if you are not able to naturally downshift or down regulate your nervous system at the end of the day without something like wine or CBD or some kind of external substance, that's a sign that you kind of reached a certain threshold of emotional debt.
quotes.speaker: Jonny Miller
quotes.context: Offers a clear, behavior-based diagnostic signal for when stress regulation has become dependent on external aids.

quotes.topic_title: Paying off emotional debt with somatic approaches
quotes.text: I'll probably get some pushback for this, but I'm not a big fan of talk therapy alone or at least therapy that doesn't have a somatic or body-based component.
quotes.speaker: Jonny Miller
quotes.context: Contrarian take that reframes effective healing as requiring a body-based component, not just cognitive insight.

quotes.topic_title: Paying off emotional debt with somatic approaches
quotes.text: What we need to do is create a certain sense of safety to kind of go into those buffered emotional responses and feel them all the way through and allow that mobilization reflex to complete.
quotes.speaker: Jonny Miller
quotes.context: Actionable somatic methodology: build safety first, then fully feel and complete stuck stress responses.

quotes.topic_title: Paying off emotional debt with somatic approaches
quotes.text: Secondly, having the practices of self-regulation so that if these things come up, you don't get overwhelmed. You're able to downshift and ground. And then thirdly, it's the practice of what I call emotional fluidity, which is basically creating the conditions of welcoming the full spectrum of emotions as they arise.
quotes.speaker: Jonny Miller
quotes.context: A practical sequence (self-regulation → emotional fluidity) that practitioners can apply to process stored emotion without overwhelm.

quotes.topic_title: Paying off emotional debt with somatic approaches
quotes.text: The neuroscientist Damasio calls it a somatic marker. So by tracking the somatic markers and then either on your own just kind of following that sensation and allowing whatever emotion was present at the time to complete that is the way that we kind of slowly pay off that emotional debt by one process at a time.
quotes.speaker: Jonny Miller
quotes.context: Concrete technique: track body sensations (“somatic markers”) and let the associated emotion complete as a stepwise way to reduce emotional debt.

quotes.topic_title: Paying off emotional debt with somatic approaches
quotes.text: when I was living in Bali, I did several hundred breathwork journeys where you breathe in a certain way to get into an altered state, and then in that place, these memories would arise of these things that happened 5, 10 years ago.
quotes.speaker: Jonny Miller
quotes.context: Specific example illustrating how breathwork can surface long-stored memories/emotions for processing.

quotes.topic_title: Recognizing dysregulation patterns: fight vs freeze
quotes.text: Yeah, so it's typically different forms of nervous system dysregulation and that shows up as it could be someone's breathing pattern if they're constantly in this sympathetic or hypervigilant state, if they're always tracking for things, looking for the worst case scenario.
quotes.speaker: Jonny Miller
quotes.context: Gives concrete, observable markers (breathing, hypervigilance, worst-case scanning) to help listeners recognize emotional debt as dysregulation.

quotes.topic_title: Recognizing dysregulation patterns: fight vs freeze
quotes.text: Another common one, and this is particularly true in the tech sector, is being very much in the head and living in the thoughts and the mind the entire time.
quotes.speaker: Jonny Miller
quotes.context: Names a specific, industry-relevant dysregulation pattern (over-indexing on cognition) that many high performers mistake for productivity.

quotes.topic_title: Recognizing dysregulation patterns: fight vs freeze
quotes.text: And there's a form of disassociation that happens as a kind of protection mechanism essentially because it's uncomfortable to be with the sensations in the body.
quotes.speaker: Jonny Miller
quotes.context: Explains the mechanism behind “living in your head,” reframing it as protective dissociation rather than a personality trait.

quotes.topic_title: Recognizing dysregulation patterns: fight vs freeze
quotes.text: Some people will freeze, withdraw, shut down and disconnect, and other people will become more aggressive, become bigger and attack and fight back.
quotes.speaker: Jonny Miller
quotes.context: Offers a simple two-pattern model (freeze vs fight) for identifying your default reactivity style under stress.

quotes.topic_title: Recognizing dysregulation patterns: fight vs freeze
quotes.text: My priority now is to downshift and kind of find a sense of safety basically in the body and then interact, then make the decision, then have the conversation.
quotes.speaker: Jonny Miller
quotes.context: Provides an actionable sequence—downshift first, decide/respond second—to prevent reactive decisions and conversations.
